executiveSummary.headline: January 2026: Sauna renaissance accelerates - New Year wellness resolutions drive 40-50% search spike, home installations surge with smart tech, and contrast therapy dominates as social wellness practice
executiveSummary.keyOpportunity: 69.1% of wellness seekers want to try sauna in 2026 (highest recovery practice interest). January peak happening NOW - capitalize before Q1 ends.
executiveSummary.criticalTrend: Soft Wellness Movement is 2026's defining shift - rejection of optimization for gentle, mindful practices. Sauna positioned as THE analog wellness ritual.
executiveSummary.urgentAction: 1) Publish Dry January + sauna pairing content THIS WEEK. 2) Launch contrast therapy protocol guide. 3) Set up World Sauna Forum June 2026 coverage (early bird ends Jan 31).

competitorContent.contentGap: No one combines destination longing + accessible science + permission to slow down in our voice. The trends are shared. The way we make people FEEL about saunas is ours alone.

competitiveAdvantage.positioning: Bridge between curiosity and practice. Not for biohackers, not for Finnish purists - for anyone who's ever wanted to just... stop. And get warm. And breathe.
competitiveAdvantage.moat: Brand voice is our competitive advantage. Soft wellness positioning. Longing over information. Practice over hack.
competitiveAdvantage.urgency: Soft wellness movement exploding NOW - we're already positioned perfectly, just need to amplify

healthResearchUpdates.study: Hot Tubs vs. Saunas Comparison (University of Oregon, November 2025)
healthResearchUpdates.finding: Hot water immersion most effective for raising core body temperature vs. dry sauna and far-infrared sauna
healthResearchUpdates.implication: Different passive heating methods have different physiological impacts
healthResearchUpdates.contentAngle: Sauna vs. Hot Tub: What Science Says About Each (honest comparison, not sauna advocacy)
healthResearchUpdates.tone: Evidence-based, nuanced - acknowledge trade-offs and different use cases
healthResearchUpdates.urgency: MEDIUM - interesting but not core to sauna positioning

healthResearchUpdates.study: Harvard Health Review of Passive Heating (December 2025)
healthResearchUpdates.finding: 19 RCTs analyzed - passive heating (saunas, hot-water bathing, hot yoga) showed mixed results. Blood pressure reduction confirmed (~4 points systolic), but NO improvement in cholesterol, inflammation, or arterial stiffness.
healthResearchUpdates.publication: American Journal of Preventive Cardiology, September 2025
healthResearchUpdates.implication: Need to moderate sauna health claims - not a cure-all, specific benefits confirmed
healthResearchUpdates.contentAngle: What Saunas Actually Do for Your Heart (separate hype from evidence)
healthResearchUpdates.tone: Honest, nuanced, science-based - builds credibility by acknowledging limitations
healthResearchUpdates.urgency: HIGH - important for editorial credibility to address mixed findings
healthResearchUpdates.brandAlignment: Fits with 'longing not information' - we're not selling miracle cures

healthResearchUpdates.finding: Adding 15-minute Finnish sauna after exercise supplemented cardiorespiratory fitness gains, reduced systolic blood pressure, and lowered total cholesterol considerably
healthResearchUpdates.significance: First multi-arm randomized controlled trial investigating cardiovascular effects of long-term sauna exposure in general population with CVD risk factors
healthResearchUpdates.publication: American Journal of Physiology-Regulatory, Integrative and Comparative Physiology
healthResearchUpdates.contentAngle: The 15-Minute Recovery Window: Why Sauna After Exercise Works
healthResearchUpdates.audience: Athletes, fitness enthusiasts, anyone with regular workout routine
healthResearchUpdates.urgency: HIGH - strong evidence, practical application, broad audience appeal

healthResearchUpdates.study: Peripheral Arterial Disease Management via Sauna (February 2025)
healthResearchUpdates.finding: Sauna bathing shows promise as therapeutic intervention for PAD. Physiological and molecular responses to heat stress mimic moderate-to-vigorous aerobic exercise.
healthResearchUpdates.implication: Heat therapy as medicine for populations unable to exercise traditionally
healthResearchUpdates.contentAngle: When You Can't Exercise: Heat Therapy as Medicine
healthResearchUpdates.audience: Older adults, people with mobility limitations, chronic disease management
healthResearchUpdates.urgency: MEDIUM - niche but important for accessibility messaging

healthResearchUpdates.finding: Research reveals what happens to body when going in sauna directly after working out
healthResearchUpdates.context: Recent publication examining immediate post-exercise sauna protocols
healthResearchUpdates.contentAngle: What Really Happens When You Sauna Right After Working Out
healthResearchUpdates.urgency: MEDIUM - timely research, practical guidance needed

perfectFit: Soft Wellness Movement - we already lead with atmosphere not optimization. 2026's defining trend aligns perfectly with 'longing not information' positioning.
Practice over hack - core to our brand voice. Rejection of biohacking optimization for gentle ritual.
Community and IRL connection - 'spaces where you belong' vs. solo optimization. Social sauna culture rising.
Permission to slow down - 'five minutes of stillness' is our promise. Analog wellness (+273% digital detox searches) IS our lane.
Healthspan over lifespan - 'how well can I live?' not extreme longevity. Quality over quantity aligns with our values.
languageOpportunities: Use 'practice' and 'ritual' when covering New Year resolutions (vs. 'optimize', 'hack', 'resolution')
Frame contrast therapy as 'the hot-cold practice' or 'shared ritual' NOT 'performance protocol' or 'recovery optimization'
Lead portable sauna content with 'bringing warmth home' or 'making the practice accessible' NOT 'biohacking on a budget'
Emphasize 'permission to slow down' in Dry January and New Year content - give permission, don't create pressure
Smart saunas: 'making the ritual easier' NOT 'optimizing your sessions' or 'tracking performance'
Research: 'what science actually says' with nuance NOT 'miracle cure' or 'game-changer' hype
avoidances: Don't use optimization language (hack, level up, high performers, maximize, optimize)
Don't create urgency or FOMO (Subscribe NOW, Don't miss out, Limited time)
Don't oversell research - Harvard study shows mixed results, be honest about limitations
Don't pressure readers - invite with 'step inside', give permission, create longing
Don't use biohacking jargon without translation for beginners
Don't focus on metrics and data over atmosphere and experience
signaturePhrases: Every Thursday: why heat heals, where to find it, and five minutes of stillness.
Close the door. Let everything go.
The sauna is not a hack - it's a practice.
There's a room with no notifications.
brandVoiceAlignment.competitiveAdvantage: Brand voice is our moat. The trends (contrast therapy, portable saunas, brain health) are shared. The way we make people FEEL about saunas - the longing, the permission, the ritual - is ours alone.

keyInsights.implication: Sauna perfectly positioned as analog wellness ritual. We're already in this lane.

keyInsights.brandAlignment: PERFECT - 'longing not information' is soft wellness embodied
